channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Counting Russia’s War Dead in Ukraine
item.description: Amid doubts about Moscow’s true war losses, Russian data journalists and volunteers use news articles, tombstone photographs and other open-source information to tally the Russian toll from the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The funeral of Russian serviceman Nikita Avrov, 20, in Luga, Russia, in March. Some researchers working to compile a list of Russians who died in the war in Ukraine visit cemeteries to check tombstones.

item.title: Where Romantic Poetry in a Fading Language Draws Stadium Crowds
item.description: That 300,000 people celebrated Urdu verse during a three-day festival was testament to the peculiar reality of the language in India.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: The inaugural day of the Urdu poetry festival Jashn-e-Rekhta in New Delhi this month.

item.title: North Korea Fires Missiles Capable of Reaching Japan
item.description: The launches were the first missile tests by North Korea since it fired an ICBM a month ago.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage in Seoul of North Korea’s missile launch on Sunday.

item.title: Taraneh Alidoosti, Iranian Actress, Arrested
item.description: The actress, Taraneh Alidoosti, had urged people to speak out after the execution of a man involved in nationwide demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Taraneh Alidoosti in May at the International Film Festival in Cannes, France.

item.title: How Can Tainted Spinach Cause Hallucinations?
item.description: A food recall from Australia sheds light on an unusual aspect of brain chemistry.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Baby spinach in a California field. The healthful green was recently the subject of an urgent recall in Australia, where some other plant is thought to have ended up packaged with it.

item.title: World Cup Final Caps a Complex Saga Between Messi and Argentina
item.description: Lionel Messi left Argentina when he was 13 and has had a complicated relationship with the nation since. But this World Cup has changed things.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Sebastián López Brach
item.media:description: Thousands of fans in the city of Rosario, where Lionel Messi was born, celebrated Argentina’s win on Tuesday.

item.title: From Behind Bars, Inmates Award France’s Latest Book Prize
item.description: For the first time, detainees picked their own winner in an offshoot of the Goncourt, France’s top literary honor.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mathilde, in her cell. Participating in the Goncourt expanded her horizons, she said: “It’s a means of escape.”

item.title: How the Xenophobic Town of Hérouxville, Quebec, Fell in Love With Immigrants
item.description: “We now want as many immigrants as possible,” said Bernard Thompson, the mayor of Hérouxville, Quebec, a onetime supporter of the town’s anti-immigrant code.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Hérouxville is quiet and mostly residential, with few vacant properties. Affordable housing is a primary concern for regional officials hoping to stimulate immigration to the area.

item.title: Leo Varadkar, Ireland’s Returning Leader, Has Lots to Prove
item.description: In Leo Varadkar’s first stint as prime minister, he embodied for many his country’s move into modernity. But after several missteps, he now takes up the role for a second time, with the glow of optimism dimmed.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Leo Varadkar in October in Dublin. He was one of Europe’s youngest heads of government at the start of his first term and was his country’s first openly gay prime minister, or taoiseach.

item.title: Russian Official in Africa Wounded by Package Bomb, Moscow Says
item.description: The official, previously identified as a senior operative with the Wagner Group, was hospitalized in the capital of the Central African Republic, according to the Russian embassy.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Elian Peltier and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Dimitri Sytyi, center, at the National Assembly in Bangui, Central African Republic, last year.

item.title: Will the African National Congress Buy President Ramaphosa’s Alibi?
item.description: A bizarre scandal threatens to topple President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa from leadership of the African National Congress, which begins its party conference on Friday. Will A.N.C. members buy his astonishing account?
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa hopes to salvage a presidency engulfed in scandal over the theft of a huge amount of U.S. currency stashed in a sofa at his game farm.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Concert in Mexico Sold Out, But Many Ticket Holders Were Turned Away
item.description: The concert was supposed to be one of Mexico’s largest, sold out months before. Instead, one of the world’s biggest stars played to a half empty floor.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Bad Bunny on stage during his concert in Mexico City.

item.title: Berlin Hotel’s Huge Aquarium Bursts, With 1,500 Fish Inside
item.description: A 50-foot-high, 264,000-gallon cylindrical tank called AquaDom, housed in a Radisson in the German capital, spectacularly collapsed, sending waves of water through the building and onto the street.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Debris outside the Radisson Hotel in central Berlin on Friday. The hotel was evacuated and the authorities were checking for structural damage.

item.title: Former Palace Aide Makes Face-Face Apology to Ngozi Fulani Over Remarks
item.description: Ngozi Fulani, who runs a charity for abused women, said a palace aide, Susan Hussey, pressed her on where she was from, dismissing Britain as an answer. Ms. Hussey resigned over the episode.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Ngozi Fulani, right, at Buckingham Palace on Friday, received a face-to-face apology from Susan Hussey.

item.title: What Russia Got Wrong
item.description: A cascade of military failures started with Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Local News Outlet in New York Faces New Hurdle: A Declined Visa
item.description: Phil O’Brien, a Briton who has run a Manhattan publication for several years, had his visa denied because immigration officials deemed his struggling business “marginal.”
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phil O’Brien, publisher of W42ST, a Hell’s Kitchen local news site, was denied a visa renewal to the United States.

item.title: Military Spending Surges, Creating New Boom for Arms Makers
item.description: The combination of the war in Ukraine and concern about longer-term threats from Russia and China are driving a bipartisan push to increase U.S. capacity to produce weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Behind Argentina’s World Cup Magic, an Army of Witches
item.description: France might have its star Kylian Mbappé, but Argentina has hundreds of “brujas” casting spells to protect Lionel Messi and the rest of its national squad.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Lankes
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Magalí Martínez, a self-proclaimed witch, is one of hundreds who has used magic to try to help Argentina’s soccer team.

item.title: Putin Visits Ukraine War Headquarters
item.description: The meetings with his top brass seemed to signal a shift from his largely hands-off public posture to one conveying a more active role in war planning.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: In a photo distributed by Russian media, President Vladimir V. Putin made a surprise visit to Ukraine command headquarters to meet with his top officers for “short- and mid-term” planning of the war.

item.title: Ukrainians Focus on Resilience a Day After Major Russian Strikes
item.description: The mayor of Kyiv said that water was back on and that the city’s subway service had resumed. President Volodymyr Zelensky urged businesses to help set up more “invincibility centers” for the public.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Ukrainian State Emergency Service firefighters clearing rubble from a building that was destroyed by a Russian attack in Kryvyi Rih on Friday.

item.title: The Best of 2022
item.description: It’s best-of season. Let’s dig in.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Revisiting an Anti-Immigrant Quebec Town Uncovers a Plot Twist
item.description: Norimitsu Onishi, a New York Times reporter, traveled to Hérouxville, Quebec, to learn what had happened in the 15 years since the town passed its xenophobic immigration code.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town hall in Hérouxville, Quebec.

item.title: When Did the Anthropocene Start? Scientists Closer to Saying When.
item.description: A panel of experts has spent more than a decade deliberating on how, and whether, to mark a momentous new epoch in geologic time: our own.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Eight Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation Into Putin’s War in Ukraine
item.description: Secret Russian battle plans, intercepts, and interviews with Russian soldiers and Kremlin confidants revealed new details of how Vladimir Putin botched his invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remnants of a Russian convoy in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: Tunisia Heads for First Elections Since Presidential Power Grab
item.description: Voters will choose a new Parliament, but under revised rules that vastly dilute the influence of political parties that many blame for sabotaging the North African nation’s 10-year experiment with democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ahmed Ellali and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A billboard in the Tunisian capital, Tunis, on Thursday encourages people to vote in Parliamentary elections on Saturday.

item.title: J. Robert Oppenheimer Cleared of ‘Black Mark’ After 68 Years
item.description: The physicist and architect of the American atomic bomb was stripped of his security clearance in 1954 after what is now called a flawed investigation.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: J. Robert Oppenheimer at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., in 1957. His security clearance with the Atomic Energy Commission was revoked in 1954 after he was accused of having Communist sympathies.

item.title: New Covid Booster Shots Cut Risk of Hospitalization by Half, CDC Reports
item.description: The research was conducted in part when older variants of the coronavirus were spreading. Other factors may have influenced the conclusions.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a bivalent booster shot at the Hebrew Home in the Bronx in September.

item.title: Death Toll in Peru Protests Rises as New Leader Struggles for Control
item.description: Two government ministers resigned after the new president, Dina Boluarte, deployed the military to crack down on the demonstrations that have convulsed the country.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of ex-president Pedro Castillo protest in Plaza San Martín in Lima, Peru, on Friday.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine With Waves of Missiles, Knocking Out Heat and Power
item.description: Dozens of missiles knocked out heat and electricity systems around the country including in Kyiv, where two-thirds of its residents had no heat or water.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Firefighters clearing the rubble on Friday at a building damaged by a Russian missile attack in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine.

item.title: Peru Protest Photos
item.description: The unrest started after the ouster of President Pedro Castillo, who tried to dissolve Congress and was arrested.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers during clashes with supporters of the former president, Pedro Castillo, in Lima on Thursday.

item.title: Leaders Mix Sports and Diplomacy at the World Cup
item.description: Dozens of top officials have flown to Qatar to cheer for teams while talking shop. The event has magnified the tiny Gulf nation’s role as a diplomatic broker.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken during the United States game against Wales.

item.title: Joe Kennedy III to be Named Envoy to Northern Ireland
item.description: With the appointment of Joe Kennedy III, President Biden hopes a marquee name will aid in promoting economic development in the struggling country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The White House believes that Joe Kennedy’s name would draw attention and excitement to Northern Ireland, a person familiar with the discussions said.

item.title: Crucial Talks on Preserving Nature Are on Now. Here Are the Key Issues.
item.description: Negotiators from around the world are meeting in Canada in an effort to halt, and reverse, staggering declines in wildlife.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: The biodiversity summit in Montreal is scheduled to wrap up on Monday, though many delegates say they expect it to run into overtime.

item.title: Israel’s Arab Allies Signal Business as Usual, Despite Far Right’s Rise
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu is close to forming a coalition with Israel’s far right and the Arab states that normalized ties in 2020 appear unconcerned.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s new far-right allies have a history of anti-Arab statements that some thought might prove too objectionable for leaders in Bahrain, Morocco and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Angelina Jolie Ending Her UN Work
item.description: Ms. Jolie, who had worked with the organization for 21 years, said she wanted to connect more directly with refugees and local groups.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Angelina Jolie at the Kutupalong refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, in 2019.

item.title: Russia Central Banks Keeps It’s Key Interest Rate Steady Amid Inflation
item.description: The country’s central bank said inflation, at 12 percent, risked rising because of a growing budget deficit.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A popular neighborhood in downtown Moscow, Russia, in October. Russia’s Central Bank warned on Friday that and that “pro-inflation risks are up and prevail over disinflationary risks.”

item.title: Suspected Crush at London Concert Leaves 1 Dead and 2 Critically Injured
item.description: The police responded to reports that a large crowd had tried to force its way into the O2 Academy Brixton, one of Britain’s most popular music venues.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Desiree Ibekwe and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Kirsty O'Connor/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The O2 Academy Brixton in London on Friday. It was unclear whether the injuries had occurred inside or outside the venue.

item.title: Congress’s Productive Final Weeks
item.description: With the holidays looming, Congress is using its final weeks to try to approve a rush of major legislation.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill enrollment ceremony for the Respect for Marriage Act last week.

item.title: Japan Moves to Double Military Spending, With a Wary Eye on China
item.description: The Japanese cabinet approved the first update to the country’s official security strategy in nine years, elevating Beijing over North Korea as the top threat.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Japan’s plan to bolster its military comes as public opinion has rapidly changed on the issue.

item.title: Missiles Knock Out Heating Systems in Ukraine Amid Freezing Temperatures
item.description: It was the ninth large-scale wave of missiles to be aimed at Ukrainian infrastructure this fall. Officials said 76 missiles had been fired, and all but 16 were shot down.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Sheltering inside a subway station during Russian missile attacks in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Fire in France Kills at Least 10, Including 5 Children
item.description: Firefighters managed to put out the blaze, in a seven-floor building near Lyon, in central France. It was not immediately clear how the fire had started.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Firefighters outside an apartment complex in Vaulx-en-Velin, a suburb northeast of Lyon, France, where at least 10 people were killed in a fire on Friday.

item.title: N​orth Korea Says It Has Tested a New ICBM Engine
item.description: ​The statement, issued Friday, followed an order from the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, to develop a new ICBM that is harder to intercept.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showing what it said was a test of “high-thrust solid-fuel motor” at the Sohae Satellite Launching Ground.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Allegations of a bribery scheme at the heart of the E.U.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Eva Kaili, a European Parliament vice president, is being investigated on suspicion of bribery.

item.title: Biden Courts African Leaders, but Some Are Skeptical of Big Promises
item.description: President Biden faced a challenge in winning the confidence of a continent where the circumstances of its leaders vary so dramatically.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the close of the U.S.-Africa summit, President Biden promised to make a visit in return.

item.title: Protesters in Peru Demand Justice for Ousted President Pedro Castillo
item.description: Eight days after Pedro Castillo’s removal from office and arrest, thousands of his supporters have joined protests demanding his reinstatement. To them, he is the voice of the marginalized.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of supporters of former President Pedro Castillo protesting in front of the detention center where Mr. Castillo is being held on Thursday in Lima.

item.title: Qatar Bribery Case Cracks Open European Parliament — and Finds Hidden Cash
item.description: Prosecutors say the glamorous lifestyle of a European lawmaker masked a Qatari corruption scandal. It exposed how vulnerable Brussels is to foreign influence.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk, Tariq Panja and Sarah Hurtes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: US To Train More Ukrainian Troops in Germany on Advanced Battle Tactics
item.description: Western instruction since Russia’s invasion has focused on basic training or the use of sophisticated weapons systems. Officials say “combined arms” tactics could be a key next step.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Soldiers at the base in Grafenwoehr, Germany, in July. U.S. trainings with Ukrainian troops at the base have primarily revolved around advanced weapons systems thus far.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Will Train More Ukraine Troops
item.description: Plus: Chinese companies are hit by U.S. trade restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training with U.S.-provided weapons used to damage bunkers near Yavoriv, Ukraine, just weeks before Russia invaded in February.

item.title: A Russian Missile in Kherson Upended Lives. Photos Show the Aftermath.
item.description: In the immediate aftermath of an attack, the horrors of the Ukraine war, the random death and the lives upended take on a deeper meaning when seen close-up.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna and Viktor Dudnyk weep over the body of their son Dmytro, 38, killed in a Russian rocket attack in Kherson, Ukraine.

item.title: Harry Takes Aim at William in New Episodes of Netflix Documentary
item.description: The younger prince made several incendiary allegations about his brother, who is now heir to the British throne.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Of negotiations over Prince Harry and Meghan leaving royal service, Harry said, “It was terrifying to have my brother scream and shout at me, and my father say things that simply weren’t true.”

item.title: UN Peacekeeper Killed in Southern Lebanon
item.description: An Irish peacekeeper deployed along the Lebanese border with Israel was shot and killed, and three others were injured. The attack is being investigated.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A group of U.N. peacekeepers came under fire in the village of Al-Aqbiya, Lebanon.

item.title: Boris Becker Returns to Germany After Release From British Prison
item.description: The tennis champion left for his home country after serving time in Britain for hiding his assets in a bankruptcy case.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The former tennis player Boris Becker returned to Germany after he was freed from prison in Britain, where he had lived since 2012.

item.title: A Look Inside New York’s Swirling Kaleidoscope of Faiths
item.description: The city is home to some of the most spiritually and culturally diverse areas in the world. Here are some of them.
item.dc:creator: James Estrin and Liam Stack

item.title: The US Imposes Sanctions on a Russian Oligarch and Other Officials
item.description: The sanctions block financial transactions in dollars with Vladimir Potanin, the largest shareholder in Nornickel, the world’s biggest producer of palladium and refined nickel.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Vladimir Potanin, one of Russia’s wealthiest men, was included in a new round of financial sanctions by the U.S. State Department.

item.title: How to Hand Out Billions in Climate Subsidies? Very Carefully.
item.description: John Podesta, the White House aide overseeing new tax credits, said rules were expected to be in place within months. Avoiding waste and fraud is a priority.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Podesta, President Biden’s clean energy adviser, at the United Nations climate summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, last month.

item.title: Covid May Spread From Corpses, Scientists Report
item.description: Family members and health care workers should take precautions, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: While transmission from corpses is not likely to be a major factor in the pandemic, bereaved family members should exercise caution, experts said.

item.title: Falconry is an Ancient Sport. In Qatar, Drones Give it a Twist.
item.description: The training regimen now involves drones, but doomed pigeons are still in the mix. Generations of Qataris have taken up the hobby.
item.dc:creator: Erin Schaff and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: US Cracks Down on Chinese Companies for Security Concerns
item.description: The Biden administration placed severe restrictions on trade with dozens of Chinese entities, its latest step in a campaign to curtail access to technology with military applications.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration required dozens of Chinese firms to work with the U.S. government to verify that their products were not being used for activities that would pose a security risk to the United States.

item.title: Nurses in UK Strike for First Time, Seeking Higher Pay
item.description: The walkout is just one of a series of industrial actions across Britain this month as ballooning inflation, rising interest rates and a recession put pressure on workers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nurses on a picket line outside a London hospital on Thursday. The strike comes as the N.H.S. is in crisis, with declining working conditions for clinical staff and amid the spillover pressures of the pandemic.

item.title: Gun Violence and Children
item.description: A portrait of an American tragedy.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
